newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Colombia governor calls for U.N. peace force.
newsitem.headline: Colombia governor calls for U.N. peace force.

text.p: The governor of one of Colombia's most violent provinces called on Tuesday for U.N. peace-keeping troops to be drafted into the area to safeguard human rights.

Alvaro Uribe, governor of Antioquia province close to the border with Panama, said an international force should be deployed in the province's trouble-torn, banana-growing region of Uraba, where leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads have killed with impunity for more than a decade.

In the latest incident, investigators said they had unearthed five corpses in shallow graves near the town of Apartado, which was also the site of a massive car bomb attack last week in which 11 people died.

"A request from Colombia for armed support from the U.N...would reaffirm our sovereignty and show the international community this is a respectable state that wishes to regain respect for human rights," Uribe told reporters after a meeting in the provincial capital, Medellin.
President Ernesto Samper rejected a similar request by Uribe last year, saying an international force would be seen as a violation of national sovereignty.

Samper and army commanders, not wanting to give an international dimension to Colombia's three-deacade-old guerrilla uprising, have also ruled out all offers of assistance from foreign leaders to mediate with Marxist rebels.

Uribe's critics blame him for fuelling the violence through covert backing of right-wing paramilitary groups and open sponsorship of anti-guerrilla civilian self-defence committees, known as Convivirs.
International human rights groups have criticised the Convivirs, whose members have the right to bear weapons, as little more than legalised death squads.
The discovery of the five dead men near Apartado appeared to demonstrate Uraba's spiral of tit-for-tat violence.

Local officials said the victims from the village of San Jose -- known as a hotbed of rebel support -- were probably killed by paramilitary groups in revenge for last Thursday's bomb attack, which was blamed on guerrillas.
